column4: wailer-- that makes sense but i want to use the hd space from the ubuntu partition because the windows partition only have 1.2g left on it.
you want to setup your machine so that it has a partition that is readable by both operating systems.   Windows cannot read Linux's ext3  and Linux cannot safely write to
-- how do i do that?
...write to Windows's NTFS.  The lowest common denominator is the DOS filesystem FAT and FAT32.  Both Windows and Linux can safely read/write that filesystem
- but my win xp is installed using ntfs, how can i convert it to fat32

Chances are that your Windows partitions (in Windows they're called "drives") are NTFS.  Chances are that all your Ubuntu partitions are formatted to contain ext3 filesystems.  Which means, you're out of luck.
you will have to repartition to enable easy sharing between teh two OSs.
of course, if the files are small enough, you could use floppies or even CD-RW
or you could use the network -- upload the file to some server from Ubuntu, and re-download it from Windows.
to my knowledge, there's no way to convert an NTFS filesystem to FAT32 -- you have to backup, re-format, and restore.  But, even if that were practical, you don't want to do that for
Windows's boot filesystem because without NTFS a good chunk of Windows security won't work.
you're welcome

- how do i repartition? i want to give win xp drive more free space coz when i installed ubuntu, i gave it a lot of hd space and leave xp with just 1.2g. how do i get xp back some free space like 5g more?

There is a tool for repartitioning but I have never used it. But when you undertake that kind of work, there is always the danger that you will lose data.  To be safe, you will want to backup your files first.
did you get the message from ubotu about GParted?
- i think its easier to uninstall ubuntu and let win xp reclaim all of the hard disk space, then make a clean install of ubuntu? what do u think?

absolutely.  If ubuntu is a recent install and you have few or no personal files on it, by all means re-install.  However, I don't think that Windows can expand its partition.  Instead, you'll have to create a new FAT32 partition that you use for sharing.  You can do that either from Windows, or from the Ubuntu installer.
-- how do i do this repartitioning with gparted
-- thanks

assuming you have just one disk, I think you want to end up with a disk partitionned like so: 1 NTFS partit (teh existing windows boot/root partit), 1 big FAT32 partit, 1 or 2 ext3 partits, 1 Linux swap partit.
